intro: Aralia macdowallii, commonly known as the Macdowall's aralia, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Araliaceae family and is characterized by its compound leaves and clusters of small, white flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, woodland habitats and can reach heights of up to six feet. Its berries, which are red when mature, are an important food source for birds and small mammals. Aralia macdowallii is also valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
